5 DEMANDS NO 1 LESS, officially withdraw extradition bill from legislature is NOT OUR VICTORY

Carrie Lam, Chief Executive of Hong Kong, announces the following actions on 4 Sep 2019 in response to crisis brought by the extradition bill.

1/ Officially withdraw extradition bill from legislature
2/ No independent probe - appointing two new members to the Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC)
3/ Reach out to the community to start a direct dialogue with citizens
4/ Independently examine and review society deep-seated problems and to advise the Government on finding solutions

It is apparent the victory of all the protesters. Yet, it is the sugar-coated poison to deceive the citizens to temporally relieve people's wrath.

The credibility of Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) is seriously doubt.

First, it is not what its name stated, ‘independent’. The members of the IPCC were somehow with their own political stance, where mainly they are Pro-Beijing (*1). The new members introduced by Carrie Lam includes Paul Lam, former chairman of Bar Council, and Helen Yu Lai Ching-ping, campaign advisors of Carrie Lam during Chief Executive Election of 2017. It is afraid that the IPCC cannot work political neutrally in handling complaints on such events.

Second, the rate of successful complaints was extremely low. Since the establishment of IPCC (2009), there were over thousands of complaints were submitted. Yet, only around 3-4% were accepted as verified. Most of the involved police members were warned only, causing no deterrent effect. (*2)

To conclude, establishing independent probe is the only way to resolve the issue.

Hong Kong citizens made it crystal clear that ‘5 demands no 1 less’.

1/ Completely withdraw Extradition Bill.
2/ Retract the proclamation that protesters were riots
3/ Withdraw criminal charges against all protesters
4/ Establish independent probe to thoroughly investigate abuse of powers by the police.
5/ Dissolve the Legislative Council by administrative order, and immediately implement Dual Universal Suffrage.

Over the past few months, the crisis aroused due to the extradition bill is far more than the bill itself. It is a humanitarian disaster that it has become. It is evident that the police adopt excessive force on the protesters, even on the pedestrians passing by the protesting scene. The lethalness of the weapons escalates from baton, tear gas to bean bag rounds, even lethal 9mm ammunition.

Since the “Hong Kong Anti-Extradition Bill Protest” began, 8 martyrs have died already. 3 eyes of our fellows were taken by ‘being hit accidentally’ by police’s bullets. 2 brave young men were harmed seriously by the members of triads with knives. Over 100 people were charged. Over 1000 people were arrested.

The real fear is not the physical harm. The real fear is the erosion of freedom and rule of law.

The Basic Law stated clearly that ‘Hong Kong residents shall have freedom of speech, of the press and of publication; freedom of association, of assembly, of procession and of demonstration; and the right and freedom to form and join trade unions, and to strike.’. In the past few months, such basic rights of Hong Kong citizens were seriously invaded. Some of the assembly were objected due to unknown reasons. Some of the citizens were arrested just because they held opposite opinions with government. Even worse, the police were biased to the supporters of the government, taking the law to their own hands. We strongly stand against the white fear brought by the Hong Kong Police and Hong Kong Government.

We will not forget our sadness and our anger, but we will keep kindness in our hearts, and we wish no more people will die for the cause of freedom, justice and democracy. We hope the society will stick together, fight against tyranny, and protect Hong Kong together. We all believe that an elected government would bring us a better future.

#5demandsno1less

What we think on the withdrawal of the extradition bill:

Withdrawal/ suspension of the bill:
The in-charge legislative council member or government official declares the withdrawal of the corresponding bill at the beginning of the second/ third reading in the LegCo.

What actually Carrie Lam said on the withdrawal of the extradition bill:

Restart second reading

Move the motion: withdrawal of the bill

LegCo members vote on the motion

過半
Over half of the members vote ‘Yes’

The bill is officially withdrawn

不過半
Over half of the members vote ‘No’

Second reading, third reading
The bill is passed
